text: johns bottle. tart rich oak with slice. very good taste though more of a sipper.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. HFD #14 Smakuje jak dobry Flanders. Takie Biere de Garde to ja rozumiem.

(2014 version on tap @ Warpigs HF Day, Copenhagen, May 12 2016) Pours a medium amber with almost no head. Aroma of red berries, caramel, sweet grape, stewed fruit, a sort of sweet-tart blend with some wood and funk lying over it. Flavour is sweet and kind of acidic, like a drier fortified wine, with toasty oak, bitter grain, sour grape, and a dry hay and funk barnyard character. Finish is rather tannic, dry and woody with a bit of grain, and lingering tart fruit notes. Medium body, lightly oily feel, soft carbonation. A bit hard to get into at first, with charms that reward some patience.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2016 2012 bottling. Red pour with a larger head, specs of lacing around the glass. Mild funky aroma, tart berries, oak, yeast, spices. Lightly sour taste, underripe berries, oak, yeast, lighter caramel sweetness. tart yet very approachable. Medium body.
2012 bottle. Aroma is berries, big oak, bready yeast, spice and very light caramel. Tastes very oaky with mild berries. Mild sourness and tart. Good.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2016 Bouteille indiqué sous Vintage 2013, embouteillée en février 2014 et bue après 30 mois. Robe ambrée-orangée trouble surmonté dun col de mousse dense, blanchâtre et assez persistant. Une fine dentelle saccroche au parois du verre. Arômes de bois, beaucoup deffluves vineuses et autres petits fruits sûrets, vinaigre balsamique, fleurs et levures sauvages. En bouche, beaucoup de petits fruits, bois, tanins de raisins, mélange dacidités citrique et acétique. Finale de petits fruits sûrets, bois et jus de citron. Texture légèrement huileuse et sèche, corps mince. Très bien mais niveau dacidité peut-être un peu trop élevé.
Sample @ Hill Farmstead Tap Takeover, Warpigs. As Norma. Clear amber body with no head. Soapy, tartness, oak, yeasty.

Draught @ [ Hill Farmsted Tape Take Over ] - Warpigs Brewpub, Flaesketorvet 24, DK-1711 Copenhagen, Denmark. [ As Hill Farmstead Norma ].[ Vintage 2014 ]. Clear medium orange red color with virtually no head. Aroma is tart, berry, farmyard, wine, funky. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate acidic with a long duration, tart, berry, wood, wine, funky. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20160512]
On tap at Warpigs. Reddish golden with white head. Aroma is tart, fruit, lactic and slight acetic, caramel and wood. Taste is similar, complex and sour. Fruit and bready malt.

Draft @ Warpigs Brewpub, Copenhagen. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty weak sour yeasty oaky aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty sour oaky flavor. Has a fruity malty slightly tart spicy yeasty grassy finish.

Draught @ Hill Farmstead Day - Warpigs Brewpub, København
Pours clear deep golden/amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, funk, caramel, fruity and some tartness. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium sour with a long slightly dry, tart, funky, caramel and fruity finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

From tap at Warpigs, Copenhagen. Clear amber copper color with off white head. Malty and yeasty aroma, caramel, fruity, light funky, wood, vinous. Sweet and acidic taste. Light to medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Bottle: Poured a brown/reddish color ale with a small foamy head. Aroma of tart notes with light fruity undertones is pleasant. Taste is also a mix of tart notes with light fruity undertones and some light caramel notes with some oak notes also clearly identifiable. Body is about average with good carbonation. Not bad but I would say that the vinous and tart level is quite high for the style.

Draught, vintage 2014, at WarPigs Brewpub, Hill Farmstead Day. Clear amber-red coloured body. Bubbly ring to the rim of the surface. Fair lacing. Rich semi-tart aromas of brown malts and fruits. The taste profile follows suit with caramel, green apple skins, and semi-tart fruits. Prolonged malt-fruity ending with underlying tartness. Fine bodied. Lovely (shared with KimJohansen and Skinnyviking, Copenhagen 12.05.2016).

Tap @ Warpigs, 2014 vintage. Clear dark amber/brown with tiny head. Aroma is malt, fruit, sour, caramel, littl evinegar and wood. Flavour is malt, fruit, sour, caramel, little vinegar, medium dry, oak, wood and a little lemon.
Sample at Warpigs during the HF event. Tart smell with wood. Similar taste with some tanins. Light tart with oak. Dry finish.

Bottle @ Warpigs, Copenhagen. Pours slightly hazy golden orange with an offwhite head. Aorma of sourness, light malt, caramel, yeast, wood, tart fruity, grass, grapes. Flavor is rather sour, yeasty, malt, caramel, oak, hay, grass, tart fruit, green apples, green grapes. Medium body, average carbonation, dry and rather acidic finish. 120516

Tap @Warpigs. 2014 vintage. Amber color with little head and low-to-medium carbonation. Tastes almost like a sour brown but sweeter - tart, oak, sweet malt, funk, stone fruit, in all honesty probably too complex for me to describe. Very, very good but also a lot going on here.

Pours clear dark amber with minimal head 
Aromas of acidic grapes, tart grapes, green apples hints of burned caramel 
Taste has tart notes of red fruits, burned caramel, oak, wood

12.05.2016, tap @ Warpigs:
Small slightly bubbly mediumlasting head. Aroma is mild sour-ish grassy, soda powder, grass, mild vinegar, sour fruits, oak, flowers, yeast, butterscotch, sorrel. Taste is slightly sour-ish dry, soda powder, oak, sorrel, weeds, flowers, grass, citrus acid, fruit salt, mild vinegar, butterscotch, minerals, bark. Medium bitterness, slightly sour-ish dry mouthfeel. Nice.
Tap warpigs. Pours hazy amber with a white head. Aroma of tart, peachy, grape, tropical, sweet, light grain, fruity, light wood. Taste is rather oakt, tarty, light sour fruity.
On tap at Warpigs. Amber with a small white head. Aroma of plum and peach with a hint of vinegar. Tart, fruity flavour with oak and a hint of honey

Tap @ Warpigs, tap take over. Vintage 2014. Clear deep amber with a small white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, wood and light funky. Flavor is quite sweet and light acidic. Dry and light acidic finish. 120516
750ml. Thanks again to Chris for sharing. Rich brown, red-tinged stringy gray head. Red malty, sour-tart, clean tart juice. Malty cranberry. Sparkling. Pretty tasty but a bit confusing.

February 26, 2016. Bottle, vintage 2014, shared by scarl, thanks! 
Slight hazy pale amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is slight toffee, ripe fruits, plum, lime zest, lemon juice, grape skins 

Taste is light tart and fruity. Finish is slight sweet with some toffee notes, oak, fruity, plum, sour berries. Light to medium bodied, soft to average carbonation.
A: Brown/red colour with a thin white lacing. N: Brett, kumquat T: Caramel, grapefruit zest, hint of cherry O: Quite bitter with a nice tartness. Pretty nice!
Bottle pour at tasting, thanks for sharing this Chris. Awesome beer to try thank you. Peach color pour. Sour aroma sweet taste. Awesome beer to try.

2013 bottle, thanks to Reynolds314. Ruddy orange brown pour. Dusty; tart; some oxidation; light caramel. Surprisingly (or maybe not so surprisingly? Expectations are odd like that) tart and tannic through the finish. Suggests to me that there was once more sweetness to this, but time has dried it out (or maybe thats bullshit -- who am I to say what time has done to a beer Ive never had except for this one bottle generously traded to me). Medium- body, slick texture.

Waxed bottle poured. Huge thanks to Chris for sharing this gem of a style I know little about. Next thing I know I am enjoying the highest rated beer in the style. Reddish orange pour with a patchy head. Sour fruit aroma. Flavor is sour orange and cranberry juice, lingering berry. How this isnt a sour, and a bier de garde, is beyond my knowledge, but the beer is fantastic. Sourness rating 7/10. Most excellent.

Flavor: Moderately tart cherry, light vinegar, yeast and mineral to start. Then roasted grain and a hint of nuttiness in the middle and then light bitter lemon pith.
Comment: Well balanced, understated and well-made.
Cool herbal nose some basement dank yeast notes. Tangy also. Hazy orange Amber thin head lace etc. super tangy some orange lemon basement funk chewy character nice mouth feel. Nice beer.
750 ml. shared bottle. Pours a cloudy reddish orange with a small white head. Aroma of fruit, wood, and funk. Taste is tart fruit, berries, malt, wood, and funk. Delicious.
Brown reddish colour, oaky, lactic, vinous aroma. High on acidity, subtle and complex. Fantastic

750 mL bottle poured into a snifter. Batch 2. Finally reviewing this after having it multiple times. Originally reviewed 10/20/2013. Very dark outside as I drink. Appears to have a nice khaki head. Murky light brownish body. Acidic nose. Malty. Lots of oak. All three aromas blend together seamlessly. Mild tart flavor. Malty. Slight citrus tang. Very oaky. Oak pulls together the flavors in the finish.
Medium body. Well carbonated. Mild sourness.
 A beer that is greater than the sum of its parts. Simple flavors put together very well.

2015 bottle drunk 7/24/15.A brilliant, rich amber hued beer showing good clarity and topped by an off-white head that shows strong retention.Wow. Not to take anything away from the flavors, but Ill be damned if HF dosent have some of the most aromatically pleasing beers out there. After the disappointing incredibly over-barreled SP Saison du Ble, the wonderfully balanced and integrated barrel character in the nose here, was supremely refreshing. Soft, aged red wine character, minerals, light chalk and very low tannin character all build complexity, as dry toffee and brown bread-like malts creep in from the edges, adding just a touch of sweetness and allowing the wild character to present itself cleanly and clearly. Limes, hickory, cobwebby cellar, mild lactic influences and peppery phenols all dance about on the nose, with the wood both softening and deepening as it warms. I smelled this thing for about 5 minutes before even trying a sip. No alcohol, no flaws.Flavor does not disappoint in the least. Soft, dry barrel character and soft, sweet malt character balance each other, while tight, ample carbonation further amplifies the softness/creaminess of the palate. Lightly acidic red wine notes, bits of oakiness and some dry mineral/chalk character build up slowly on the palate, as tart, lemon-lime-like brett notes add brightness and a bit of sharp acidity, as well. Lactic acids soften things, adding a pinch of mild yogurt/cheese-like character and it ends with soft malt and wood character trailing off, with pleasant, not-overdone acidity lingering lightly, as well.Whew. What a beer! Over the course of this amazing weekend, trying all kinds of delicious, highly rated beers, I think this one would only be matched by Ann itself. And to think this beer had only 4 months in the bottle at this point. All signs point to this beer with 1-2 years of age on it being absolutely divine; the light touches of sharp acidity from the yeast/bacteria should soften, as well as allowing for the wine/barrel character to integrate just a little more. As it is, though, Id be happy to drink this fresh any day of the week. Rating is for this bottle I had, but also the potential I think this beer has for being even better aged.  Could very easily trying an older bottle and giving it a 5.  Hope that happens!Huge thanks to Adam C for opening this!

Bottle: Thanks, Adam! Soft red/orange body. Cloudy with a small, gray-white head. Aroma is tart with notes of light white vinegar, vanilla, wood, red grape skins, a hint of cheese rind, mild cherry. Tart cherry skin flavor, mild vanilla yogurt, oaky tannin sharpness, grapes, light cobweb funk, small bit of leather, dry woody finish. Lovely.
Pours an opaque orange with a slight orange head. Aroma is grapefruit, hay, barnyard and slight funk. Taste is grapefruit, lemon, hay and barnyard funk.

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. Pours a lovely reddish amber with a off white head. Aroma has cherry, funk, oak, slight syrup, lots of fruit and is very dry. Taste is tart, citrus peely, very funky and dry. Slight caramel and honey sweetness to balance.Slightly boozy. Very delicate and elegant barrel character. Fairly full body and average to high carbonation. Very nice!

Bottle shared. Pours cloudy amber brown with a small tan head. Aroma of big vinous notes, strong oak, tart light fruits, grapes, also tart overripe dark fruits and a touch of caramel giving it Flemish brown qualities. The honey also comes out with lightly floral notes as well as a nice light bretty funk. Flavour is moderate sweet and light moderate sour. Over medium bodied with light carbonation.

Bomber courtesy of and shared with Kermis. Big thanks.
Funky aroma. Thin creamy off white head. a mixture of sweet and sour in the aftertaste. Nicely balanced

Bottle thanks to Bursprak. Pours cloudy amber with a white head. Aroma has a nice farmhouse-styled dryness along with some citrus notes, some oak, green grapes, weak elderflower and classic HF yeast strain funk. The taste is tart and fresh with notes of green apples, grapes, oak, white wine, barnyard and with a dry end. Balanced and nice beer.

Bottle shared at Dangerous Bottle Share 12.0. From a trade on BA. Hazy amber pour with a decent white head. Nose is tart, red berries, vinous and light vinegar. Taste is oaky, vanilla, tannins, leather, light tartness and some honey notes.

Bottle @ Travlrs Satellite 10k Shindig. Slightly hazy amber pour with a small off-white head. A pretty musty beast. Plenty of rich malts, caramel, Attic. Floral hoppiness and grape stones. Taste is brighter. Accents of tropical fruits, mango. A touch of honeyed melon. Reasonably lean. A touch of tartness on the finish. Easy drinking. Nice.

Big thanks to Bursprak for bringing the HF-goods :) Pours dark hazy orange with a thin white head. Aromas of vinegar, champagne-like notes, tart red berries, gooseberries, sweet esters, lots of funk, oak, leather. Taste is bretty, funky, tart red berries, dark malts, vinegar, earth, woody musty notes, leather. Not a style that can get me all fired up but pretty darn good anyway!

Biere de Norma is my first Biere de Garde and a strange creature in terms of flavor. Norma is redolent of rotting fruit, sour yeast, vinous grape, and tart apple. Its fizzy body and reddish hue will make you think of sparkling wine rather than beer. Taste leaves nothing to question, though. Lots of funk and earthiness here. The oak adds a somewhat musty, bittersweet character to this brew. The sour aroma and funky flavor get some getting used to, but this is a one-of-a-kind brew with class to spare.

(Thanks, Adam! "AdamJackson")

Bottle.

A- Sour, tart, funky, citrus, apple.

A- Mahogany color, clear liquid, off white head.

T- Sour, tart, dark fruits, citrus, funk.

P- Medium body, average texture, medium carbonation, sour finish.

O- My first Biere de Garde so I really cant comment on how it compares to the style although seeing the ratings its obviously the best. To me this is more of a sour red/brown but who cares, either way its a solid beer. Pretty sour but still manageable.

Bottle via trade, pretty sure I won this one because I only sent a BoT for it. Pours a reddish murky Amber with a small off white head. Aromas of plain yogurt, oak, fruit. Taste is heavily lactic, medium tart, not sweet but not dry. Flavors of creamy yogurt, wood, some dark sour fruit, funk. Not puckering, but plenty on the sour side. Not sure its a "Biere de garde", more like a sour red/brown. Nonetheless, this is outstanding. Bravo!
Bottle. Great aroma, funky, citrus gooseberry, leather. Taste is lovely too. Fruity, smooth, light funk, little sour, grapes. Mega!
Pours beautiful amber, nice foam. Aroma has loads of barnyard character, nice acidity, apple cider. Taste is also very similar, sour, barnyard, brett. Very nicely done, super enjoyable.

Lovely russet amber color, almost glowing. The head quickly disappointed. Huge oak, Brett, slightly sour nose, horse blanket and wet leather. The mouth is fairly sour with lots of leather, horse blanket. The aftertaste is nice and sour that goes on and on with lots of oak and leather.

Bottle shared by Brandon! Thank you so much! Pour is cloudy red with a small thin white head. Aroma is stunning - musty with red grape, light funk, Light wood, and Earthy. Flavor is quite salty up front with earthy and mineral notes to follow. Also notes of Wood and earth. Tastes like gose. Aroma is perfect.

Amber colored body with a medium sized off-white head and spotty lacing. Assertive oak, earth, lightly sour stone fruits, some vinous notes, some semi-sweet grains. Medium to full bodied, moderate carbonation, muddled finish.

Bottle courtesy of Vinny at Ryans. Pours a deep hazy Amber with thin white lacing. Aroma is light wine, sour fruit and oak. Mouthfeel is deep and full with notes of dark fruit, oak, light mineral and malt.

2013 vintage. Pours a copper color with a modest head. Smells earthy, sour, oak, yeast....wish I could better describe this one. Taste: assertive sourness; oak, sweet malts as well, but the tartness is dominant. Medium bodied, below average carbonation; dry, tart finish.
This poured a reddish color with a white head. Aroma was of light vinegar. Cheese, apples, and.Brett. Flavor was similar, bretty tart vineous sour brown

Shared bottle with a friend 2013 version. Thanks to Keith for sending me this one. Deep cloudy Amber / red-Ish colour with a white head. Ripe green apples, vinegar, cinnamon, grapes, citrus, dust, oak, wine, some sweet long finish, honey maybe, cherry, brett, barnyard. New flavours after each sip you take. One of a kind beer. Boy what a great brewery
Bottle shared by beerman6686 at the bachelor party. Pours a cloudy pale ruby orange color. White head. Aromas of sour apple, pineapple, funk. Taste is sour. Crisp tart finish. Medium body.
Bottle thanks to Dan. Poured cloudy amber with caramel cream head. Aroma funky sour apple. Light carb med bod. Tastes tart sour drying grape fruits

Bottle into a snifter. Nice color, a deep scarlet. One finger of dense sand-colored head pops away quickly, leaving behind spotty lace. The resident microflora did their work here. Balsamic vinegar, barnyard funk, cherry, flashes of toast and rose petals in the aroma. Steady tartness in the flavor. Not too big, not too small. Rocket pop sweetness, a little caramelized sugar, touch of cherry, underlying barnyard funk, pithy tartness on the sides of the tongue at the swallow, touch of oak, a hint of baked bread. Medium-light body, heartburn from the tartness, gentle carbonation tickles the tongue. Tartness builds as the end of the glass nears. Kind of a cross between Biere de mars and Flanders red. Interesting blend.
bottle, copper orange red pour, oaky biere de garde with red apples, caramel notes. funky yeast adds a nice dimension. Another great beer from HF

75cl bottle courtesy of and shared with Sarro and Omgrich. Thanks for sharing it Kyle! 2012 anno, ltd# 1200. Bottle# ?
De couleur acajou, col épais crémeux blanc-cassé.
Arôme pointe sur un léger fruité rouge avec en retrait une note mielleuse qui adouci les effluves. Léger malté cara, avec un rétro boisé légèrement suret.
Palais au caractère rustique avec une once de fruité rouge (venant peut-être des levures?). Note un léger impact du miel qui offre une petite rondeur à chaque gorgée sans pour cela être trop présent. Le profil boisé donne un fini légèrement épicé qui se marie bien avec le côté sauvage des levures. Ceci étant on peu continuer de débattre sur la nomenclature cachée derrière une Farmhouse. Parle-t-on de saison de bière de garde, ici on parle de bière de mars. En létat on reste dans une interprétation américaine du style hennuyer.
From a bottle (75 cl), courtesy of _angst_. Clear amber, low head. Fruity, acidic, notes of red apples. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry with medium acidity.

Bottle received in trade. Pours hazy goldenish brown with a frothy offwhite head that leaves a small trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is fruity, slightly malty and funky with crackers, biscuits, , caramel, grapefruit, lemon juice, moist hay, wood, barnyard, pineapple and lemon zest. Taste is sour, tiny bitter, slightly malty, slightly fruity and slightly funky with biscuits, dark bread, grapefruit, pineapple, mango, moist wood, grape skins, hay, dry soil, barnyard, kumquats and lemon zest. mouthfeel is soft, dry, tart and medium bodied. Finish is sour, fruity and funky with biscuits, dark bread, grapefruit, lemon juice, pineapple, hay, dry soil, barnyard, leather, kumquats and lemon zest. Nice

(Bottle) Pours orange red with a small head. The aroma holds red apples, funk, tight malt and lacto. The flavour is dry, light bitter and medium acidic. Funk, lacto, wheat, white bread, fruits and a touch of hops. The mouthfeel is tart and fairly clean with a medium carbonation. Light to medium bodied.
Bottle 12 - pours light caramel color. Nice light sour nose. Slight sour taste, caramel notes and balanced. Damn good!!!

Bottle at Hill Farmstead Beer Makers Dinner at Øl & Brød October 11th. Pours honey peach with a medium white head. Aromas of oak, funk, honey, caramel and ripe apple. Taste is honey, caramel, ripe apple, citrus and funk. Mouthfeel is lively with medium carbonation.

750ml bottle. Hazy orangish amber with an active off white head. Big funky aroma with caramel and oak notes. The flavor its mildly tart and bretty with a long tart finish. Medium-full body with lively carbonation. Freaking Hill Farmstead. They crush it.

Pours hazy copper with low to medium off-white head. Aroma of grass, green grapes, citrus, gooseberries, apples. Taste is medium fruit tart, mellow sweet, light lingering sour finish. Light and crisp body with soft to average carbonation.
Bottle. Ruby brown pour with tan head. Nice try fruit, light yeast and nutty aromas. Some tart fruit flavors, backgrounds are close to a Biere de garde, yeasts, malt tones, other tartness.
Hazy golden. Small white head. Little lacing. Sour Brett aroma. Taste is tart fruit with an acetic note.
Red pour. Nose is lactic, funk, tart apple skins. Taste is tart apple, funk, bitter pulp, grapefruit. Medium smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle, shared at the satellite 10K tasting CBC Clerko, 19/08/14.
Heavily hazed golden amber with a good sized light beige covering that retains well.
Nose is tarte fruit, funky vibes, musty wood, light peach, citric peel, grassy notes.
Taste comprises tangerine, woody rinse, bitter apricot, tangy citric rinds, oaky wood, bretty, funk.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid stuff.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle share at the satellite 10k tasting at the craft clerko. Thanks Leighton. Clouded orange skin red coloured pour with a lasting loose white halo. Aroma is light earthy orange peel, caramel, alcohol. Flavour is tart berry, some clean brett, apricot. Palate is crisp highish carbonation. Long lingering fresh fruit. Slightly sweetness.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2014 Bottle big thanks to Thomas. It pours hazy golden amber with a thick white head. The nose is soft, doughy, woody, white wine, wood, damp leaf, orange muffin, light vinegar and mild spice. The taste is tart, woody, vinous, damp leaf, wood, must, some acidity, fruit cake, gooseberry, sponge cake and light metallic notes with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Nice depth, but a touch musty and acidic. Not sure how much I could drink of this, but its nice in small measures.

750ml bottle (b3) pours semi clear hazy ruby red with a finger of head. Nose is musty dark woody fruit, a touch of copper, tree bark, vinous, old oak. Taste is dry, damp woody vinous fruit, dark cherry, red apple skin, tart, red grape, light funk. Finish is dry medium-low tartness, wet tree stump, light fruit, oak, grape, wine.

Bottle thanks to Will. Pours a cloudy orange red with small frothy white head. The aroma is strong honey, oak, and funk. Medium mouthfeel with nice light honey wheat, oak, funk, sweet finish. Very nice

75cl, Vintage 2012, new exclusive American brew, with honey, thx alot to Secret Santa!, very complex sour brew, floral/fruity and slightly woody/vinous, balanced, cloudy, good head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2014 750ml bottle. 2013 batch. Slow gusher. Pours out eventually a slightly murky orange/brown shade. Big sticky head with chunks of lacing. Instant bretty, farmhouse aroma, with fruity apple and grape skin notes. Plenty of all that on the tongue as well. Starts off a little sweet but then turns dry and oaky. Quite a creamy feel to the palate. Nothing out of this world but certainly a wonderfully crafted rustic beer.
Pours a reddish brown with no head. Aroma of oak, funk, malt. Taste is bitter, sour, malty, oak and funk. Bitter and sour.
The least sour of the lineup at the very sour wheelhouse. Malty and floral aroma. Slightly tart with a nice hit of farmhouse pepper.

Bottled. Medium dark brown, cloudy, with lace. Lactic nose, caramel, honey, lemon, earth. Tangy flavor of lemon and grapefruit, earthy, caramel, salty. Soapy body. Subtle and nice, without being as mind-blowing as other beers I have had from them.

Bomber. Light sour fruit nose, yeast, honey, funk. Sour apples and peaches, light bittering, a bit of barrel. Medium dark straw color. Medium body with medium astringency. Subtle fruit flavors, which dissipate slowly on the tongue and palate. Seems stronger than 7%. Nice one.

Bottle thanks to willrunforbeer. Pours a beautiful red with small white head. Nose is very funky with some barnyard. Rustic. Taste is quite puckering initially. Slightly drying and thin. This is the most liberal example of the style but it is still quite nice. A touch sweet to be a saison and a touch too funky for a typical BdG. Very nice.

Another share from Homer. Pours a ruby red, white head, pretty beer. Aroma is a bit sour, tart, oak, yummy. Taste is tart up front, the jaws clenched a bit. Mouthfeel is light, def mouth puckering, but not overpowering. Later sips relax the jaw clenching. Tasty beer for sure.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2016 2015-07-08, tasting at Matts, vintage 2014, 8-4-8-4-16=40Hazy bright amber color. The aroma has some cedar wood elements, some sourness, Brett character. Smooth and acidic mouthfeel, good body structure; the flavor is dominated by the wild yeast, it has an excellent woody character, and a nice fruity touch that complements; astringent in the end.Excellent.2014-01-18, Danish tasting session, 7-3-8-4-16=38Gushing bottle; pours a muddy dark amber color with large frothy head. Sour and a bit fruity aroma, with hints of vinegar and hazelnuts. Good body strength; it has a moderate and pleasant residual sweetness, a good yeast character, controlled citrusy acidity, lingering fruitiness, medium to low bitterness.Could be better if more controlled and cleaner, but its clearly a good beer.

Bottle shared at hoppy loft. Pours medium brown with an off white head. Aroma is floral, fresh peaches, citrus. Flavor is very smooth, soft. Some peach, green apple. Finishes tart green apple. Not what I expect in a saison, but quite nice, whatever this is!

Bottle from a year ago. Deep hazy orange with a sightly off white head. Nose of oak with different levels of beautiful funk. Taste: amazing. Malty funky sourness with a hint tartness near the end. Finishes with a mild boozy buttery oak taste.

Bottle shared with Mathieu87 and WillRunForBeer. THX!
APPEARANCE: clouded dark blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: fruity, citrus, hoppy, flemish old brown beer?
TASTE: fruity, hoppy, citrus, little dry, bitter, nice and fresh, sour, apples. Dont know what type of beer this is, but its pleasant!

2013 Vintage. 
Aroma is fairly fruity with a lot of stone fruit and light apple cider notes. Hint of citrus and some faint pepper and coriander. Medium light maltiness with some toasted bread and caramel. 
Pours a fairly cloudy brownish orange with a copper hue and a thin tan head that recedes quickly to the edges and disappears. Light lacing and small legs. 
Flavor has a light to medium light acidity with medium light malt character; toasted bread, light caramel and crackers. Medium fruitiness with lots of overripe stone fruit and hints of citrus. Light peppery phenolics and medium light bitterness. 
Mouthfeel is medium light bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth.
Overall a pretty enjoyable beer with a lot of fruit notes and some light phenolics. More malt character than I would have expected, but it works fairly well. Touch of mustiness.

Bottle @ Yespr, thanks! Pours unclear orange/brown with a frothy off-white medium head. Aroma is complex, earthy, lactic, wood, toffee, citrus and unripe fruit. Taste is light+ sweet, bitter and tart. Body is light+, texture is smooth, carbonation is soft+. Finishes dry, tannic, minerally and tart with wood.

750 ml bottle. 2013 vintage. Great looking red/ copper color with some head retention in a tulip. Aroma shows tangy berries, oak, hints of Brett, juicy fruits. 
Flavor is very nice. Vinous grapes, light yeast, mild barnyard, Caramel malts, with a nice mellow oak toward the back end. Hints of citrus fruits. Just a lot of different nuances in this brew. Great level of complexity. Medium in body with correct level of carbonation. Very dry texture. Excellent brew.

Bottle. Pours deep amber with thin white head. Mild but tart aroma. Super tart sour flavor. Not my taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The beer pours out a dark copper-amber color with a tiny scrim of caramel-white bubbles that mellow into a nice ring around the glass. In body, the beer is nearly a uniform color throughout with a rich opacity. On the nose, this beer reeks of beautiful funk; lemon-lime and horse blanket tango on the nostrils alongside nuances of pineapple, leather, cherry pie, and deep barnyard scents. What a beautiful nose on this beer. On the tongue, the beer tastes of a wonderfully balanced tartness alongside a smooth malt sweetness and just a kiss of herbal and spicy hop bitters at the back and finish. As the beer warms, a smooth and syrupy sweetness also starts to blanket the tongue throughout the sip, further pressing a nice balance throughout the beer. In flavor, the beer begins as pineapple juice and light caramel, slowly working its way to sweet barnyard and horse blanket. The finish blends horse blanket, caramel malt, pineapple juice, herbal hay, and grass notes onto the tongue. Soft touches of pine and this delicious yet unplaceable sweetness splash over the back of the palate. The aftertaste is a delicious blend of caramel and funk, almost like a softly candied funk. In the mouth, the beer is on the light side of medium, with a soft carbonation and a mouthfeel that is smooth and slightly syrupy. Overall, this is delicious and a perfect candidate for aging. The funk will only get better. Sometimes I want to dislike Hill Farmsteads beer, but I never can. This beer is great.

Bottle, 2014 batch, shared by AdamJackson - thanks man! Pours cloudy burnt sienna with a small tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is light tart, some funky notes, lots of oak tannins. Flavor has a lot more nuance than the aroma, lots of oak tannins, fruity, currants, some vinous notes as well. A bit of initial sweetness that quickly dries out. Light tartness, some zesty bitterness and a bit of funk as well. Medium body, enjoyable beer.

Bready, fruity, a bit funky, tart, sort of like a melange of flemish brown, flemish red, and a hint of saison, extremely interesting beer bursting at the seams with flavors. Not always my favorite flavors, but a damn impressive beer nonetheless.

2012 bottle from a trade with cpetrone84, thanks Chris! Pours a nice golden amber, sparkling carbonation, spongy off-white head that breaks down into nice lacing. Very lively nose. A nice tartness is present among the floral/earthy aroma. Like fresh picked flowers. Some musty Brett wafts out, lending a bit of oak as well. Taste is moderately acidic with notes of green apple and pear. Mouthfeel is lively, giving it a champagne quality. Vinous notes across the barrel character. Very nice and balanced. Finishes fairly tart and dry. Excellent beer.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2014 Bottle at Yesprs - Thanks. Cloudy amber/brown - white head. Fruity and herbal aroma, earthy, minerals, citrus, orange, light crispy, yeasty, acid, nice fresh oakey notes, spicy. Ok - not fantastic...... ReRate: Bottle at Øl & Brød - Hill Farmstead Dinner. Cloudy brown - white head. Apple. Fruity. Sourness. Vitamin. Light wooden. Light coconut notes. Fruity. Herbal notes. Toasted. Nice acid. Light oak. Tartness. Lovely.

Booming brett aroma with oak. Copper gold brilliantly clear. Amazing brett flavor really dominates the body which is nice and full bodied. A wow beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Aroma. Citrus, sweetness, yeast, some fruits, light oak. Flavour. Fruits, sweetness, oak, spice, yeast. medium to full bodide. Ends light fruity, citric and sweet.
Pours a dark rust in color. The aroma is oak forward with some earthiness and funk. Wine and berry. Finishes tart, but not sour

Bottle at yespr.
Hazy orange-red coloured with a small off-white head.
Fruity and light acidic aroma of red wine and berries.
Fruity and light acidic flavour of red wine and berries.
Tart finish.

shared by yespr,
gusher. cloudy brown, small white head.
aroma is sourish, wild yeasty, not that biere de garde like, as it is clearly sourish, but thearoma is pretty nice. spicy woody notes , wild yeasty notes ,sour beer notes.
flavor is very sour, spicy base, wood, pretty good clean us style wild yeasty beer.i like the subtle pretty tart grapefruity stingy notes hiding underneath. delicate, complex.

Bottle. Gusher. Unclear orange with a small off white head. Bretty, berries, wooden, citrus notes. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Medium sweet and light bitter, light dry, light tartness. Soft and mellow, but complex. Good stuff, thanks to yespr for sharing.

Bottled. An unclear amber beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of fruits, malt, caramel, brettanomyces, and wood. The flavor is sweet with notes of brettanomyces, malt, caramel, wood, and berries, leading to a bitter finish.
Bottle. Hazy orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, fruit, hops and sourness.

75 cl bottle, slow gusher. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is fruity, mild citric to orange. Wooden. Smooth fruity, citric. Mild fruity, citric and crisp.mellow. Fruity and crisp. Lingering fruity. Smooth, elegant.

Bottle. Hazy amber liquid with medium off-white head. Aroma of lemons, bread, apples, wood, funk and light earth. Taste is dry and light to medium sour with notes of lemons, bread and toast. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Really nice.

750mL bottle, sent from 22 oz. bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks a lot, Dany), pours an opaque dark orange amber with big white head. Aroma brings out lots of wood, wild yeast, and light tart tannins. Flavour brings out exceedingly complex notes of brett upfront, followed by wood, earthy notes, and more wild notes. This stuff is amazingly complex - no sourness at all, but lots of wild, funky notes. Remarkable depth to this beer. Awesome stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2015 750ml bottle in a tasting glass. 2011 version. Pours hazy amber with an off-white head. Aroma of a nice tartness, light oak, some floral notes, light fruits, and caramel and pale malts. Flavor a great blend of the tartness and everything else. Smooth texture. Really good. Edit: 2013 bottle.  Pours hazy, deep amber with a lacy off-white head.  Aroma of tartness, oak, some wine and grapes and fruits, and nice caramel malts.  Flavor the same with a great blend.  Smooth texture.  Amazing.  2015 version.  Still great!

750 ml bottle with red wax. Poured from a limbic basket into a Hill Farmstead wine glass. Pours a darker copper with a beige head of foam. Dark fruits, cherries, fruity funk. Nice acidity in the taste with a mild sweetness throughout. Dries out in the finish. Moderate carbonation.

A: Reddish/Amber Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Red Wine Barrel, Funky, Yeast

T: Currants, Yeast, Mild Red Wine

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying

Overall, too much hype...good but not great.
At SARA West Ashley line/tasting. Very good saison/sour. Not sure if I'll remember it, but but it was very good. Excellent.
Bottle from International Trade; reddy brown pour with soapy tan head, fruity aroma, sweet honey taste, raisins, sour and the trademark HF funk going on excellent beer, best Ive had of this style.

3k rating. pours unclear burgundy with a small light beige cap, little retention and lacing. juicy and spicy concoction - red grapes, marmelade, peaches, red fruitiness, some sweetness, tannic but welcomed woodsy notes, caramel and toffee, pepper, coconut, tart and dry palate - bretts, aceto and lactic notes. low carbonation, medium body - oily, sweet, astringent bitter tea and slightly chalky finish. outstanding..

Thanks to czar for the opportunity, congrats on 3K too! Pours a hazy copper with no head and thus no lacing. Aroma is really fruity, with peaches and tangerines being the main culprits. Taste is also really fruity with peaches at the front and lightly tart. Some sweetness in there too enhancing the fruit juice feel of this concoction. Carbonation was kinda low but it doesnt detract you from the awesomeness. Some grapes and a winey feel. Medium body, insane drinkability. Awesome!

Pours clear and amber with a soft carbonation that leaves a sticky ring that hugs my glass. The aroma is of sweet malts, yeast, light spice, oak, mild vinegar, and fruit notes. I taste oak, yeast, cherries, tropical citrus tones, and a mild vinegar flavor. The finish was of yeast, fruits, and a tart character. Overall a very good beverage.
Bottle. Cloudy reddish amber color. Aroma of funky cherry, berry, rhubarb. Tastebis softly sour summer fruit, red berries. Nice.

Bottle. The pour is a very hazy orange. The aroma a little sour but has some nice aroma. The taste is a little light in the flavor overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2013 Bottle thanks to Adam.  Shared at the Amarin Cafe. Pours orange brown with tan head. Nose and taste of caramel, farmhouse yeast, berry funk and strawberry jam. Medium body.

Bottle @ Armins apartment, courtesy of Steve_0. Thanks so much! Pours a very hazy red orange appearance with a tan head. Really a tangy, spritzy, orange citrusy, barnyard, somewhat oaky, cherry, somewhat tart aroma. Somewhat vinous, big grape, cherry, bretty, funky, spicy yeasty flavor. Not what I would have thought from the worlds best Biere de Garde but it is DAMN GOOD!

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, huge thanks to Stephen for cracking this gem! Dark reddish pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of lots of spice, oak, bread, caramel, some slight red wine vinegar, slight oak, nice vanilla, hints of red wine and grape notes. Taste is a mix of sweet red grape, hints of oak, wine notes, hints of spice, caramel toffee, hints of red fruits, touch of dark red fruits, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter, oaky. Interesting, but not what I expected.

Bottle at Armins shared with friends. Pour is deep amber with a big white head and great lacing. Fruity, floral, lightly spicy, tangy, citrusy, caramelly, doughy, light biscuity, and orange peel in the aroma. Taste is extremely well-balanced, spicy, fruity, tangy, floral, doughy, bready, lightly funky, grassy, earthy, and herbs with a crisp dry finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Very fruity, spicy, malty, yet tart, sour, and extremely drinkable. Just an awesome beer. Wow!

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2013 Bottle at tasting in VT and with Joe, acquired at the release. Pours hazy ruby with whiteish head, medium in size. Aroma of red berries, black currants, jam, citrus, potpourri, red grapes, and oak. Flavor is tropical hibiscus, wood, rind zest, grape skins, cherry and yeasty funk. Medium carbonation with a perfect palate from the oak. Really complex and layered brew from HF. Unbelievable. Sweet caramel and oak.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2015 *Critique cahoteuse de la St-Jean Baptiste, batch 2012: Explosion dagrumes habité par le cocktail de levure tellement habile. Elle a été séparé en 4 mais je laurais facilement géré seul.**Batch Jan 2015: Terreuse, vineuse, poivrée, tannique, filiforme et fruitée. Elle présente des notes de grillottes en finale, élégante minéralité, ma note ne change pas.
Bottle share. Hazy amber. Wish I have more. Aroma is cherry, wood, honey. Taste is basement, cherry, candy, so much wood. Ugh!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2013 Bottle thanks to Tommy. Nice red colour with a small pale head. Aroma is red currants, sour plum, candy, bbq sauce. Slightly creamy mouthfeel, good body, well balanced palate. Taste is red currants, sour plum, cherry, loganberries. Omg this is so tasty.
Citric perfumey aroma, maybe dragonfruit, enchanting nose, hard to really figure out, smooth lightly fruity flavor, some mild tartness and grains.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Cloudy brown red with white head. Sour, cider apple, green with margarine undertones and vinegar in the nose, Sour, delicate rhubarb in the mouth. Carbonated, full-bodied, delicate finish.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2013 Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Pours deep ornge hazy with a nice head, aroma of brett, cheese, yeast, vanilla, wet soil, fruity sweetness, flavor is sour with lambic character, vanilla, apricot, wood, red wine leaves, medium to full bodied, great

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Ariel. Cloudy dark orange-amber with a white head. Lovely funky and fruity aroma with barnyard, oak, some sweat, spicy notes and some citric notes. Sourish flavor, very oaky, with fruitiness, lots of brett, earth, and some lemony notes in the finish. Medium-bodied, rounded-mouthfeel. Great.

Une créature brunâtre sur laquelle flotte une petite mousse des Flandres. De ses entrailles se dégagent les parfums dune bête spontanément sauvageonne. Jaime ce nez rempli de notes boisées imbibées de raisins et touchées par une flore microbienne. De son goût naissent des notes raffinées de chêne, de noix de coco, de fruits acidulés, de caramel et de brettanomyces. Dans ma bouche sinstalle un corps proprement huileux qui me permet dapprécier davantage cette uvre. La finale, boisée et astringente, organise une attaque élégante dirigée pour le bien-être de mon appareil gustatif. Tout compte fait, une création singulière très stimulante et excessivement facile à boire. Bien content davoir pu mettre la main sur cette concoction qui semble néanmoins ébranler la définition du style.
murky ruby, puffy cream head, large lacing. Nose is cherry skin and white pepper, heavy red wine but no acetic notes. Flavor is heavy cherry, sugar, tea, balanced but sweet.
It is spicy but tart, very prominent wood flavors, not the depth malt breadiness I was looking for after aging.

Pours a rich rusty copper color with a fluffy white head. The nose is very vinous with great barnyard brett, soft pear and hints of citrus and hay. The palate follows the nose with a nice round honey wheat bread that provides a great platform for the funky barrel brett, vinous fruit, dusty earth, stone fruit hints...very complex yet balanced with a focused dry woody finish. Great beer!

Pours a clear reddish with small beige head that doesn't hold long. Smell is oak, fruity, funk. Taste is absolutely beautiful. Nice balance between light caramel, oak, red berries. Lacto is present without being overpowering. Nice Brett character. Mouthfeel is medium low. The only thing I would say is that it lacks a bit in carbonation. Definitely a piece of art.

Bouteille de 750ml. Capsule métallique sous une grosse couche de cire rouge. Un gros 20 piastres à la brasserie de Greensboro. Bouteille partagée avec Patrick. Liquide brun orangée avec une mousse beige. Le nez semble presque simulé le vin rouge avec du boisé et des raisins. Il y a aussi des bretts. En bouche le liquide est comme le nez, du vin rouge, des raisins, des bretts. Cest piquant et la texture est agréable. Un touche de levure coco en fin de bouche.

750 ml bottle shared at Cams tasting. Thanks again! Pours a clear red-amber color with an off-white head that lasts only as a ring. Clean aroma, with lots of vinous character throughout, notes of flowers, apples, lemon juice, oak, herbs, and only light funk. The flavor has more tropical fruits; very vinous, as well. Mildly acidic. Citrus juice. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation. Excellent beer. Really refreshing.
2013 release. Funky grass and hay, farmhouse blankets, yeast at the forefront. Layers of depth, mild tartness; tastes like blend between a gueuze and saison. Shaun brewed yet another winner.

750ml red waxxed bottle into a tulip glass. 2012 vintage, 1200 bottles. Shared moments after returning to CT from the Norma release on an outside patio in the cold. Cant beat it! Quick notes I jotted down.

A - Pours a cloudy dark red body. Messy off-white foam.

S - My first thought was of a Flemmish bruin. Has a lactic twang with some cherries, vinegar, apricot and plenty of oak. Some musky saison notes with a touch of caramel. 

T - Tart cherries and vinegar, caramel malts, funky earthy notes, fresh apricot, and some light oak and vanilla. Really complex and tasty. The finish was unreal though. The beer was incredibly tart and then it just vanishes away. Medium bodied with nice carb.

O - The first half of the glass left me a bit underwhelmed. The more I thought about the beer the more I liked it though. Its incredibly complex and unique. Super tart with a perfectly clean finish. It drinks way too easily. Certainly worth the effort to get a bottle in person.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2013 Bottle shared with Ernesto.  Pours an amber copper color with lively tan head with good retention.  Aroma is nice lemon, nutty maltiness, light toast, balsamic.  Taste is prickly tartness with a lot of woody oakiness and vinous notes and light vinegar.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2013 Completely flat, no head. Too bad, would be amazing but with a flat body its just flavored water. Will definitely rerate when I try again, asking around this was an islocated incident


After opening another bottle,  oh my god....... Im speechless

750 mL 2011 bottle.  Thanks Tucker.  Shared shortly after the Ann release.

Pours a generally clear ruby brown with a large off white head.  Long retention and sticky, thick lacing.  Nose is a complex blend of sweet bread, malt, woodsy and earthy oak, vanilla, and yeasty spice.  Flavor is more of the same as the nose, funky and earthy, spicy yeast and oak, mild vanilla and malt sweetness.  Medium thick body, prickly carbonation, mild tartness in the finish. Just wow, as nice as Ann was, this was the standout for me.  Edit: Early sample of the 2012 batch was equally special, with a little more barrel (port like) and fruit presence than I remembered from the 2011 bottle.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2013 pour is orangish red with an off white head leaving a decent lace. Nose is heavy red wine, juicy dark grape, notes of oak, very rustic and pleasant. Taste is solid, the red wine is there. juicy dark grape.leather light behinf, slight brett presence. Body is light, assertive carbonation, and a touch of dryness to it.

Dark amber pour.  Nose is grainy, wine forward but quite balanced. Rustic, great barrel and grain working with cherry, stone fruit. Mouth is a bit oxidized, malty, lots of red berries and red wine barrel. Great nose with some great rustic qualities, but a bit overly oxidized and malty in the mouth. Feel is soft washing carbonation, pleasant.

In short: An intense, sharp, tart, citric, oaky, wild amber amber.  Unique creation.
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed approximately 4 months after the beer release (first batch, only batch so far).  Split two-way
The look: Cloudy amber-orange body topped by a small beige head
In long: Nose is bright brett, plenty of freshly cut oak, some citric fruits, a countryside sensation.  Taste is uber-rustic, tart red and light color fruits, plenty of oak tannins, woody white wine, something that resembles raspberry seeds, strong farmhouse character, lemony citric notes, fresh oranges.  The oak is coming out strong in this beer.  Crispy mouthfeel with an aggressive carbonation.   This tasted like a blend of 50% wild oaky Sour ale and 50% uber-rustic blond Saison.  As far as style is concerned I thought this was closer to what ratebeer usually classifies as a Wild/Sour then the current style Bière De Garde.  An excellent beer but very razor-sharp and not as highly drinkable as all other Hill Farmstead wild ales, this is almost a sipper.  I should add that my brother thought it was the best Hill Farmstead he ever had, but he doesnt rate and I do, I think Biere De Norma is just on par with the average standard of excellent Hill Farmstead quality, a great beer.  Impossible to find, but with I drink a beer I dont care about superficial things like how rare or how hyped the beer is, I only care about meaningful important things, like how jealous tickers will be that I drank this beer.

Small pour thanks to Lushawn and his woman winnning a bottle and sharing it on the spot! Appearance is a dark golden color and the nose is light fruit, floral, some yeast and subtle funk. Taste is a refreshing mix of white wine--gewurztraminer and sauv blanc--, lemon, pear, and grass with a touch of sour. Medium body with medium carbonation. Finish on the dryer side. Reminded me a bit of Averys Sui Generis in some regards.

Bottle number 10/300 shared at the HF Harvest Fest by either Ernesto or Lushawn, or Lushawns lady, whoever it was that won this at the raffle.  Pours a hazed orange gold with a thin white head.  Sweet musk, soft floral yeast with a light touch of alcohol.  Phenols, spicy yeast and musk.  Medium bodied, tropical fruit, warm yeast.  Acid, light funk, a touch of acid and toast.  Citrus, musk, acid, floral toast.  Long musk, toast, soft acid.  Musk, long but very gentle acid, a touch of plum to it.  Faint funk lingers for a while.  Beautiful.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2014 Bottle shared in NH, and a huge thanks to Wallace for sharing this very special beer. Pours cloudy, orange-gold with a soft, creamy head. Lots of funk in the aroma, some tart, citric fruit hints. Medium sweet flavor, great funk character, some oak notes. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation. Quite dry to finish with assertive funk, mild tart citrus impressions, some subtle doughy malts, and a quenching dryness. Wonderful beer. Quite a lot of nuance in this one. (Summer 2012, Score: 4.3)Bottle shared during the satellite Travlr 10K tasting at CBC Clerkenwell - London. Newer batch (brewed early 2013, maybe). Pours unclear pink with a creamy white head. Lovely stuff, with pleasant leathery fruits, berries, soft funk, some bready sweetness. Light to medium bodied with average carbonation. Lightly tart on the finish with lasting leathery berries. Superb. (August 2014, Score: 4.3)

bottle # 10.  ky and i somehow happened to win a bottle of this at the hill farmstead canned food drive auction.  so big thanks to shaun hill for this one:) cracked open about 5-10 minutes after the raffle with some neat beer dudes.   glouglouburp and his brother were also there :/   this beer was pretty good.   some old world rustic sourdough bread, soft pear brett, touch of lemongrass.   dry.  best biere de garde ive ever had.   an honor to try this wonderful biere.

750ml bottle. Poured an amberish color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of some yeast, citrus, caramel wood, and some lighter spice. Tastes of caramel, citrus, some bread, lighter spice, and some fruits.

Pours amber with a golden hue and a lacey creamy white head. The aroma is light, tangy yeast. The flavor brings delicious, juicy yeast with notes of fruitiness on a bigger, outstanding body for the style.

Bottle generously provided by Gonzoillini. Thank you Tony, Ive been interested in trying this for a very long time.  Pours a cloudy brownish orange in color with very little head on the pour. I wanted to note that the bottle foamed out of the neck after opening, so keep an eye when opening. Nose is interesting and I dont know if I exactly like it. There is honey, white wine, hops, and some band aid characteristics. Not bad, but its peculiar. Taste is better, its more focused on the white wine and lemon characters. There is some grassiness to it, it is faintly hoppy and somewhat saison-like. Mouthfeel is light, carbonation is light to non-existent, gentle acidity, and a short to moderate finish. Its one of the better Biere de gardes Ive had, but probably not the best. Still really thankful to try it, thanks again Tony!

Bottle shared by Wally and AdamJackson-- thanks! Pours golden with a trim white head. Smells of seaweed, cucumber, salt, sweat, and caramel malt. Tastes of white wine funk, bread bough, Candi sugar, honey, steeped grains, aged hops and lavender. Ends with minerals on the tongue. Lovely!

Bottle #269. Enjoyed in a Hill Farmstead Glass. 

A - Dark golden orange. No lacing. Minimal head. 

S - Wow. Smells nice. Lots of citrus, some funky yeast and some vanilla.

T - Up front with honey taste. Almost a mead up front taste. Mild bitterness but not too much. Floral notes, roses and hibiscus. Some sweetened candi sugars. Finish is this dry champagne like belgian yeast.

M - 20% carbonation. Light body. Grape-skin finish.

O - This was a very special beer. It has an exceptional taste. Truly a phenomenal world-class beer.

Burned orange pour, a light fluffy head.  Wonderful yeasty qualities jump out of the glass, some rich fresh oaky notes, a bit of unripe stone fruit, bready malts.  Flavor is so light on the tongue, I get the oak, some great lively yeast.  So flavorful.  So wonderful.  Wow.

My Bottom Line :  
White wine, citric tartness and lean cereals meld in this salutary rural quencher.

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A veil of foam covers the hazy pale amber.
-Cereal contribution is long and engaging. 
-Citric tartness is higher than the usual Hill Farmstead Saisons.
-Even though this was excellent, I would say full flavor cohesion had not been reached yet. Had I had another bottle, I would have kept a few more months at least.
-The big, prickly bubbles could have been a tad softer, if I have to nitpick.

Bottle.

Huge, huge thanks to yourefragile for sharing this beer.  Served in a Hill Farmstead wine glass.  Pours a light reddish-brown color with a short tan head.  Good retention and a good bit of lacing throughout.  

The nose carries some typical biere de garde character, with some semi-sweet malt and a touch of bread, followed up with a nice oak component.  Also there is a bit of cherry alongside some faint acidity.  The acid component grows through the flavor, leading the way to an exquisite mouthfeel -- dry, tart, and a nice bit of oak.

Even after just having Ann, this was a beautiful beer and one of the better ones Ive had in a long time.  A great take on the biere de garde style, without being in name only.

Bottle thanks to yourefragile. Thanks! Served side by side with HF Ann. Like a boss.

Served in a Hill Farmstead wine glass.

The beer is hazy and dark orange with a half inch of off white head.

The aroma brings oranges, citrus, malt, grass, light spice. Smells great.

The initial flavor is malty, followed by some earthy citrus. Again, very well done. Light spice, grass, tangerine.

Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

Another winner from Shaun and Hill Farmstead. More confirmation that HF is one of the best breweries on the planet.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-05-2012

Bouteille de 750 ml, merci beaucoup à Martin ! Arômes assez intenses de chêne, de vanille et de brettanomyces. Touche vineuse. Robe orangée et plutôt trouble, effervescence assez active et belle mousse qui tient bien. En bouche, le fût de chêne et les brettanomyces sont également à lavant-plan. On retrouve une belle acidité, surtout lactique et citrique et peut-être très légèrement acétique. Très belle texture veloutée. Finale sèche et acide. Une très bonne bière, mais peut-être pas la création la plus raffinée de Hill Farmstead.

Bottle This beer rocks! Pours murky and orange with a small, creamy, white head. The woody, funky, acidic nose furnishes oak and fresh fuzzy fruits and tropical fruits. Medium-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and modest carbonation. The flavor is tart, fruity and bready. Finishes tangy, accompanied by a mild yeasty bitterness. Many thanks go out to landhoney for popping the top on this world class Bière de Garde! Not too many world class Bière de Gardes in circulation. Of course, this isnt really a straight-up Bière de Garde.

Bottle courtesy of Seth.  Hazy burnt orange pour with a white head.  Sweet and sour aromas.  Mild tartness, some notes of a nectarine or peach that is not quite ripe yet, and a strong caramel malt characteristic.  Good body and carbonation.  A real nice session beer....

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2013 Bottle 750ml. N. 100. Thx alot Tom.
Pours hazy dark golden with low white head. Nice lacing. Aroma is of fruits, brett, citrus, hops, yeast, oak, vanilla. Taste is of alot of fruits, citrus (grapefruits), bretts, alchohol. Outstanding. Overall: As mentionned by other fellow tasters, reminds of TDD Dulcis Succubus. Nice bretts. Full bodied. Glad I had the chance to drink that.
[Rating for Batch 2:
Bottle 750ml.
Thx Czar. Pours deep orange/dark salmon with low beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of fruits, malt, sugar, bretts. Taste is of fruits, malt, sugar, slight alcohol, some acidity, bretts. Hints of bitterness. Palate: medium body. Decent carb. Overall: Very good. Outstanding. 4/9/9/4/17]

Shared by turdferguson.  Cloudy red orange pour with one finger of crackling off white head.  Nose is fruity and zesty with vinous oaky notes and lots of pineapple.  Lemongrass and a lovely acid/ester balance.  Nice tartness and acidity with a peppery and prickly carbonation.  Some citric notes.

Pours hazy orange with medium white head. Nice lacing. Aroma: hops, bret, fruits, citrus, and candy sugar. Amazing! Taste: bret, citrus (grapefruits), fruits (bananas). Fruity sweetness, Nice sourness. Nice balance. Medium bodied with slight carbonation. Overall, an astonishing, refreshing beer!

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2012 Bottle 750 ml (# 100). Hazy orange with a small persistent off-white head. Lacing is amazing! Aroma is of brett, oak, ton of fruits (grapefruit, grape, peach and still counting) and slight vanilla. Taste is explosive fruits and brett with oak and slight vanilla. Interesting sourness. Grapefruit is very present at finish. Lively carbonation. Crisp beer. This one taste like a boosted TDD Dulcis Succubus. Great one!

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2012 Bottle.  Deep glowing pinkish orange with steady off white head and lots of lace.  Nose is aromatic, but not expressed as forcefully as the flavor.  Tart cherry, oak, lemon, wild yeast. Flavor is fairly tart, some yogurt,  and a very minerally character in the middle, caramel malts, ending with a sour twang. A very interesting take on the Biere de Mars (or Biere de Garde style, dont know if the names are synonymous ).   Shaun says saison on the label which is possible too, but I think it drinks like a sour ale.

Draft at Tria Fermentation.  Poured a light amber, less hazy than other HFS offerings, with a sizable white head.  Aroma is pleasantly filled with black cherry, sour green apple, and slight Brett funk.  First sip introduces palatable sour cherry followed by hints of oaky vanilla and a tart crisp finish.  Flavors linger to dance on the tongue and play with the palate.

Draft at tria... Murkey orange/red in color. Average head. Great tart nose on this one... Taste is a slightly tart saison like beer. Flowers, dry, some spices, but with an over all dry tartness that linger in the after taste. Really clean and easy to drink. Light body, well carbonated, Overall my favorite beer of the tasting.

Bottle shared by sean9687 at Fountainhead. Pours an attractive glowing orange with a frothy white head. The nose is tight with clean brett, good and funky farmhouse notes, cherry and lemon zest and some faint cereal notes. On tasting, quite dry with a medium tartness. More cherry and lmeon, quite earthy and drying finish. Again, clean Brett and a really nice yeast complexity overall. A pleasure.

Bottle. Pour a nice hazy golden orange color with a white head. Aroma is kind of tart, I get white grapes, sour green apple, pear, brett funk of barnyard and wet hay, dusty old flavors, subtle oak, white wine vinous notes and some sugary and spice notes. The flavor follows the nose with some tartness, nice brett funk of barnyard and wet hay, subtle oak, lots of white wine vinous notes, dusty old flavors, green apple, pear, subtle banana, sugar and spice notes. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a really nice and interesting brew!

750 ml bottle shared at the Perennial/Half Acre Event. Thanks, guys! Pours a rich amber element, good healthy orange glow with a healthy haze. Frothy offwhite head sits atop and laces ok. Frothy overall with a firm glowing element. Aromas are rich citrus, gentle pear and crab apple. Touches of funky brett, touches of oaky tannins, mellow dry dust and cobwebs. A touch of sweetness, malty bread, and mellow fruity pear, apple, and faint banana. Touch of citrus. Initial is lighter bodied, offering a firm zesty citrusy and tart sour affront. Lactic elements, sour fruits, yogurt with lemons, touches of grapefruit, grass. Crab apple, pear, gentle tropical fruit element. A touch of sweetness. Middle is more creamy, lactic, and touches of bread. Finish is touches of oak, yogurt, trailing fruit of citrus and lively sourness, gentle brett elements but really well done. Nose and front end are spectacular. Rich sour fruits, melange of flavors. Backend trails a bit but keeps on point. Really well done.

Bottle. Hazy dark gold pour with white head, very pretty, almost glowing orange. Aroma has some brett, peach, lots of oak, vanilla, light buttery aroma, honey. Taste like TDD Dulcis, grape peel, honey, grain, butter, vanilla, very tasty. Not really sour but has a nice funk and a tart, citric finish. Palate is well carbed, and full bodied. Delicious.

Mildly bracing acidity and a undercurrent of ambient lemon zest. The barrel self-effacingly lurks on the back end with that familiar essence present in many of the farmhouse style brews coming out of the these Vermont hills. Tasting this and Phenomenology (draft) side by side was arguably one of my best Hill Farmstead moments to date.

Lightly hazy amber color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of brett, wild yeast, honey, vanilla, cherry, and light wood.  Taste of vanilla, honey, wood, caramel, cherry, brett, and light bourbon.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2012 this spend just about a year in oak according to S.E.H., thanks for the sample. pours a cloudy deep copper color with a small head. smells tart and malty with a moderate funky presence. taste is quite tart, probably the first time Ive tasted something with this type of lemony, acidic sourness from HFS. taste begins with the tartness and mild tropical esters and funk, minimal wood flavor. taste lingers for a bit. mouth feel is light and very dry. most surprising is that its actually lemony sour. very drinkable.

750mL #196 red wax thanks to oteyj. Glowing, rustic, full murky pour with huge head formation and rocky, yellowish lace. Excellent. Nose is excellent nectar fruits, huge juicy peach with hints of rusty earth than dissipate. Peaches and cream abound with whipped cream sweetness. Taste is Hawaiian sweet rolls, rich grain, mild butter, sharp lactic tanginess, bleu cheese funk, lemon zest, key like pie. Palate is excellent. Extremely quenching with mild sweet roll and sweet funky cheese rind. Mouth watering brine. Way easier to drink than Mimosa. Could chug a pitcher of this so fast which makes me think saison is still the style or perhaps sour/wild since the lactic sourness is much more pronounced than the subtle, doughy character of their saison anthology. Easy 5/5 for palate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle #196, red wax top. Murky gumwood colored pour with a large, vivacious head. Nose holds absolutely gorgeous cheesecloth, oaky tannins, brie with big washed rind, plum, apricot, orange zest, and white pepper. The flavor is even more vibrant and stunning, with beautiful mango, pineapple, tart yeasty funk, lactic sourness, a bit of kiwi and starfruit; just an outrageous fruit profile that blends so amazingly well with the lactic sour presence. Neither is overwhelming. The palate is really outrageous, completely quenching and limitlessly quaffable. Wow. Once again from Shaun Hill.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2012 Bottle 195, 750ml capped with red wax. Lively foamy carbonation upon opening the bottle- poured it fast to avoid wasting the sweet nectar. A deep cloudy orange body yields a robust lasting fluffy white head. Amazing funk and lactic acidity in the nose rounds out with notes of bretty cheesecloth and nectar fruits. The flavor is amazingly vibrant and super dry. Earthen brett, quenching lactic acid, champagne, and stone fruit pulp abound. Medium body with caressing fluffy carbonation, a quenching palate, and a bone dry finish. An incredible experience.
